reviewText: OK so its not going to win any awards.  I bought this DVD because I enjoyed watching it on T.V. about 20 or 30 years ago. Seeing Michael Beihn and Mark Wheeler is definitely easy on the eyes. It was also fun to see rising stars in support roles, like Timothy Hutton and Rosanna Arquett.It is just a sweet, clean family movie.

reviewText: Suzanne Somers follows the path of other sexy blondes such as Dorothy Malone and Jayne Mansfield by starring in a beach movie. However, it is clear in this movie that Suzanne Somers is the star and rightfully so. Movie doesn't have much of a plot but keeps you entertain because of Somers' sensitivitiy and sexiness toward the other teens. Somers goes to the beach to forget about her problems and as a result helps others with theirs. Movie is also nice to see future stars in small roles including Timothy Hutton, "Ordinary People." Rosanna Arquette, "Desperately Seeking Susan," P.J. Soles and John Carpenter, the co-writer of the movie, make a special bond before they starred in success in "Halloween." Kimberly Beck, childhood long time friend of Rosanna Arquette, is very attractive in movie and many people don't know she played the deaf mute girl Kim in the t.v. show "Peyton Place." Now, you know. Suzanne Somers proves she had star quality and is still a prescence with us in today's entertainment society as a writer and frequent t.v. guest. She is still gorgeous. In this movie, she proves she has the magical quality of Farrah Fawcett, Marilyn Monroe and Loni Anderson. Joyce Dewitt eat your heart out. Enjoy, great film for Suzanne Somers fans.
summary: Great Star Prescence From Ms. Suzanne Somers

reviewText: Long before softcore fare like 'Beach Heat' began appearing on late-night cable, the surf zone was only slightly less titillating. Babes have been strutting their bikinis in front of buff dudes on the sand for about 50 years now. In the 1960s, Frankie, Annette, and Elvis ruled the beach before Pamela Anderson and the Baywatch lifeguards patrolled the 1980s and early 90s.  But in between appeared a little made-for-TV movie called 'Zuma Beach' (1978) -- in my opinion one of the the greatest PG-rated, non-nude T&A; flicks ever. Althought its headline "Star" was Suzanne Somers -- the blonde bombshell who at 31 was at the peak of her 'Three's Company' fame -- the big attractions for me were the trio of beach bunnies this movie introduced to me for the first time: P.J. Soles, Tanya Roberts, and 18 year-old Rosanna Arquette. Indeed, you may not even recognize the bubble-gum popping Arquette here with her leering smile and delicious layer of baby-fat, but trust me that her appearance (literally) is worth the price of admission.All these girls and several others spend every minute of screen time in bikinis (Somers in a one-piece). In addition to these now well-known cast members, there's also a couple of lesser-known nymphets in featured roles. I can't positively identify the blonde in the purple bikini top with pink bottom, but from the IMDB credits I would guess she's Shelley Johnson.  The girl in the black bikini with the ridiculous Texas (Southern?) accent is Kimberley Beck (22), who had a long but fairly low-key career. Delta Burke is credited, but I never saw her. However, the cast includes some future male stars as well.  A young Timothy Hutton plays a lifeguard trainee, and a barely recognizable 21 year-old Michael Biehn serves as the stereotypical bully of the beach.Zuma is nothing but fluff and fun (unlike the similar but far superior little indie drama/comedyCalifornia Dreaming (VHS)which appeared a year later and badly needs DVD release), but it is VERY attractive fluff.
summary: Birth of the modern teen beach movie and T&A masterpiece
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just watched this movie this past Sunday night and I'm still thinking about it on Friday, what a magical little under the radar film!Got this film because of Suzanne Somers but wow, the stars were out in full brightness in this movie, so many pre-star celebrities that i actually lost count!Having grown up around beaches i took them for granted and now that I am  no longer close to the ocean , i miss it, but this movie kinda helped me with that, it really places you right down there on the water, unlike some films where the focus shots are only on the actors , this was shot from an angle that made you feel like you were sitting right there on the beach! Can really relate to that need that Suzanne's character felt to get away from it all and just relax and get inspired!Really love the way all the kids on the beach embraced her as one of their own, i say kids because is implied early on that she is supposed to be a bit  older than the others at Zuma beach.Highly recommend this hidden gem  which i could certainly see becoming one of my favorite movies! :)
Title: N/A
